Good relationships just happen sometimes. You fall into a relationship with someone. It can be effortless when two people are a good fit. I dont know any other way. Hunting for a partner doesnt work well for many of us. Definitely had horrible luck with it myself.

In the age of the internet you can look by using every single social media dating app you can find. the more contacts you make, the more lures you throw out, the better your return odds.

the funny thing about finding a partner that fits is that, despite what you just wrote about being blackpilled and old for your age, there is 100% a woman out there who meets your criteria for looks and behavior, and she would click with you like a key in a lock in terms of where you both are in life right now. That's what love is. a big part of it. effortlessly connecting with someone and youre both attracted enough to try dating. but as I wrote above, waiting for that isnt so good. so the bigger net you cast, the likelier of meeting a compatible woman. without fail. that even goes for real life. if a woman you're attracted to begins talking to you, give it your best shot and see where it goes. be present in the moment. be alert for women looking at you a little too long. or talking to you about something mundane, and instead of brushing them off or getting nervous thinking "nobody likes me", give it your best shot and see where it goes.

What kind of girls are you hitting up? You have to remember that girls mainly want one thing from relationships: containment. They want a guy who is going to make them feel safe, secure, and comfortable in their own skin. So ideally you should only be hitting up girls who are:

>shorter than you by 2+ inches
>younger than you by 2+ years
>clearly more feminine than you
>less ambitious than you
>not much wealthier than you
>not much wiser than you

If you're using dating apps you can figure most of this stuff out by their profiles and photos. Of course, you still have to take chances. But focusing on this stuff should ideally help you get rejected less because you'll stop reaching out to girls that you know are "high risk" for you.

Your life isn't without him. You have the memories. The feelings. The desire. He has become a part of who you are. I understand.

You can learn to see him in others. To appreciate the qualities he embodied, yet also come to appreciate those that they do as well. Falling in love isn't something most people anticipate in the first place so it doesn't make much sense to deny the possibility of it going into the future either.

The question becomes whether or not you will spend the rest of your life lamenting something that may never change or whether you will carry those powerful positive experiences forward with you in the hopes of one day making many more such memories.

It takes time. It took me a decade to learn how to make those feelings work for me, but it can be done.

I don't see a future for myself, at least in some aspects of life.

I'm nearing 40, divorced, no friends (every friend I had moved far away over the years due to their own life circumstances) or any form of social circle, I work as a freelancer from home so I don't even have coworkers. Whatever hobbies I have are the kind I do on my own, I've no interest in social hobbies and activities, and although I'd like to have a social circle, frankly I hate people nowadays. I don't even like to drink, so even booze-fueled interactions are out of the question.

Went to a gym for a while, but had to stop because I broke my foot. Not even while working out, I was crossing the street and took a wrong step. It's healed but still hurts when I walk too much, and to be frank, the injury took all the fight out of me.

I'd been getting a lot of work for a while, like unreasonable amounts, which meant I managed to save some money. But for the last several months, it's gone down a lot and I'm running out of savings. I still have work, but it's not enough and not from the usual and preferable sources (who just today told me things aren't optimistic on their side either).

While I don't expect or ever want to get back with my ex-wife, I know she's with someone now, and it still hurts.

The only good thing in my life is that my kid is with me most of the day, almost every day. Believe me, I know how blessed I am by this; I can't imagine how much fathers who are kept away from their kids must suffer.

So the only future I see is that I'll continue struggling through work at the very least until the kid manages to become independent and no longer needs my financial support.
I'll make no friends, I'll find no happiness, I won't change at all, I'll merely distract myself with trivial things, and the only true, significant joy I'll have is the time spent with the kid.

I know the problem is me, I limit my own possibilities.
But I can't see myself walking any other path.

Sorry for venting.

>>27994112
Relationships with sharp disparities (age, wealth, sexual experience, background) break down much more often than those between compatible people with similar traits. Relationships arising out of "power dynamics" as you call them, are inherently transactional (at least at first) while the ideal scenario with balanced relationships is that they select for strong personal and emotional connections.
That's not to say that transactional relationships can't eventual work out and become something more meaningful, it's just that they tend to fail when time passes and the law of diminishing marginal utility erodes the main reason for the relationship.

posts.sub: Keep forgetting what my girlfriend tells me
posts.com:
How do I retain information my girlfriend tells me about her and information about our relationship?

I have a pretty poor memory in general but it never really became a problem until I got my first (and current) girlfriend. When I like a girl I'll ask them a lot of questions because I care about them and want to know them more, which my girlfriend appreciated and she'd do the same back. However it's becoming apparent that at least half of what she tells me will be forgotten, because I'll end up asking her the same question multiple times or I'll have a surprised reaction to something I should already remember.

It's becoming a real problem in the relationship as she'll take it personally, thinking that I must have forgotten because I don't care about her enough. Even worse is when it comes to sweet/romantic moments she remembers fondly and I don't remember. Even if I genuinely recall them after she jogs my memory, she's got no way of knowing I truly remember or if it's just me pretending to. My poor memory was initially funny to her and she'd tease me about it, but as time goes on it's increasingly pissing her off and sometimes she'll refuse to even tell me anymore because she thinks it's a waste of time. On the other side of things, if I *do* remember something that's more trivial she'll sometimes become annoyed that I remember those things over things about her/us.

Any tips on how I can remember better? I already keep a list of notes on things I think will come up again, but it's not something I can look up mid-conversation without her knowing and it's also hard to find the information I'm looking for as the list of notes grows. I'm 28 years old so my memory shouldn't be this bad yet.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>27996514
Machine operator work isn't fun. Believe me, I'd fucking know. Entry level machine operator work is mind numbing and soul rending. When I first started machine operator work, I was expecting to work with the machines and fix whatever issues they had and really get in there in a mechanical sense. The truth is, most of your time is a machine operator is going to be spent standing in front of the machine watching it do its job. Maybe you're feeding it. That's about it. Some places are pretty chill, but most places I've seen are strict as hell. This one place I worked at had cameras everywhere, when I got hired they had this big meeting explaining to all of us new hires that they watch everything and you can't hide anything from them.

It can be a low trust environment especially entry level to mid level. If you get into the mechanical stuff though and become a CNC machinist or similar, then you're respected a little more and you even get to do some programming. That's when shit gets fun and that's also when you get paid pretty well too. Not as well as welding though on average. Most of the machine operating places I worked at hired people through temp agencies. It's like they couldn't keep people there for any longer than a month. God only knows why. That being said though, it's a big market and you're guaranteed to find something at least. Might not be pretty, but something. Like I said, if you want to do machine operating focus on becoming a machinist. A machinist works on machines and operates machines. A machine operator, just operates the machine. The difference being, One is a serious profession that pays well, and the other is basically unskilled labor.

Most machinists make around 55k per year. Some make 77k-100k. But that's rare. Machine operators usually make $15-20 per hour. I quit machine operation for a career in engineering. That was years ago. It's a solid job, but if you're like me and you need a puzzle to solve, this job won't be for you.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
It’s an identity and a set of behaviors.
As an identity, being normal means wanting to be like everyone else, to “fit in”. It comes with a sort of enthusiasm for your community and a desire to make others comfortable with your appearance.
As a set of behaviors it means doing the things that are expected of you. These expectations are perceived (Look what Billy is doing, he’s so cool/helpful!) or explicit (Don’t drive on opposite side of road).
Ultimately it means subscribing to your location. Keep in mind “normal” people are aware of intruders and liars. If your adoption of normalcy is forced it will be fairly obvious to everyone except maybe children and foreigners.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>27998318
"Normal" is a VERY wide classification, and no two people within it have everything - or sometimes anything - in common. What defines "normal" is that, in spite of all their differences, they find ways to get along, speak the same language, share social conventions and generally get along.

"Non-normal" people may be no further out than some of the others, but they can't or won't co-exist civilly.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>27992673
Dreams are your brain flushing out the excess emotions of the day, for much the same reason you flush a toilet. To do it, your brain dresses up the emotions in specific plot or situations drawn from your memory and imagination banks.

The factual details of your dreams are not significant - they're just what the brain picked at random. It's the emotional content - in your case the feelings of being trapped and endangered - that are the key. SOMETHING in your real ife is overloading you with those emotions, and the dreams are getting rid of them as much as possible.

Figure out what makes you feel dread in real life, and either change it or find ways to cope with it, and the nightmares will go.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
So it is primarily a depressant - a GABA antagonist. As a result it primarily reduces anxiety. But for some people, including myself somewhat, the process of increasing blood alcohol concentration produces a euphoric effect too. Coming off of alcohol (hangovers) means your blood alcohol is decreasing and you're stuck with acetaldehyde.
I'm an alcoholic too but I can manage it to the point it doesn't seriously affect my health/finances. Here's what I do:
>try to have days off AT LEAST once per week, occasionally I'll make it Sun-Thu
>drink plenty of other fluids with salts in the morning to manage dehydration
>take thiamine supplements, to avoid permanent brain damage and mitigate any potential withdrawal symptoms
>buy at least approximately the cheapest alcohol by money per unit
>wait until the evening to start if you can

The reason we wake up a few hours after alcohol is because it makes us pass out when it's in our system and fall asleep easier - yes it is a depressant - but as we metabolise it while asleep that effect wears off and then you get a rebound effect. Sort of like how if you stop giving a patient morphine their pain will come back.
Godspeed anon.

that is all true. the rebound (for anyone who didnt know what is going on) is the body's response to a CNS depressant. the brain produces less of some things and more of others to nullify the CNS depressant. thats what withdrawal is. a serious situation where your body created tons of stress hormones to keep you alert, and also stopped producing calming chemicals because it didnt need to while you were taking whichever CNS depressant. after 5 days of being drunk your body is overloaded with stressors and empty of relaxants. so when the chemical is metabolized, you are left in an awful situation that takes hours to weeks to resolve.

Alcohol is a pointless, fruitless endeavor. Ever since I invented a workaround for it, I've had literally no reason to drink besides taste tests and parties.

These are bad and you shouldn't be after this. Face your issues and stop getting addicted to shit that keeps you from facing your issues. Good example >>27990831

For me, I realized that I was drinking because it made me more social. I was loosened up. My anxieties, fears, etc went away. So, I just found that groove of getting loose and having a good time/letting shit go, and after some practice I realized I can let shit go and have fun without the need for alcohol. I can have the same fun, exhilarating experience that alcohol promises, minus the alcohol. All because I knew what it does to me mentally.

Now he is able to casually indulge in alcohol when we're out on dates or celebrating a special occasion and doesn't go on binges. I know that LSD was kind of instrumental in his decision to make a change because he would feel acutely aware of the physical side effects of his drinking when he was tripping.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Naltrexone for alcoholism treatment

An addict wanting and trying to quit is a case of the rational mind deciding to stop, while the autonomous processes of the mind create cravings. Its why people have such a hard time losing weight. Rational mind chooses to lose weight and eat less, autonomous mind sends craving signals. One can understand a behavior is worth quitting and try his best to quit, yet repeatedly fail against incessant, powerful urges. Worth noting is that gambling, sex, compulsive overeating, alcoholism and drug addiction are a cluster of similar disorders. A malfunction of the brain's "reward center". See for yourself: https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/18241634/

Naltrexone is a helpful medication to remove the cravings. Classed as an opiate-antagonist (binds to endorphin receptors w/out "high"), Naltrexone comes in a once-monthly injection or daily pills. Absent insurance, injection is expensive and pills are inexpensive. Public health clinics, aka "community clinics" receive federal and state cost-reduction grants to serve people who lack insurance. Sliding-fee scale for most services and in the case of Naltrexone injection, often free. In the U.S. you can call 211 in most cities, a direct line to United Way. They will help you locate such a clinic. Also some anti-depressants and other psychotropic medications can help. Addicts tend to have mood or other psychiatric issues that are called "co-morbid factors". A doctor at a "community clinic" can help with that also. Naltrexone is typically taken daily for 3+ months.

Drugs.com has 500+ positive reviews about Naltrexone from actual alcoholics.

"Medical detox" refers to a doctor prescribing librium or valium for a few days to get you safely off alcohol. It works and its painless. Trying to "taper down" WITH alcohol is slow and extremely painful. Most doctors will readily offer you a medical detox prescription.

>>27998332
As someone who is recovering from the same shit
The same way negativity snowballs, positivity will as well.
Start small, at the end of your next shower turn it cold and writhe in it for as long as you can physically go. Cold showers are good for you, and its a way you can force yourself into an uncomfortable but positive situation for yourself without leaving your home.
Thats a small win, from there go onto cleaning whatever needs cleaned, this might be your downloads on your PC or your room.
As you get more small wins, you get more confidence to get larger ones.
For me in the past few months here is how that has expanded
>Watch Jojo
>Start working out at home
>Start doing things like talking cold showers, change real soda for diet soda and other dietary changes like no candy and minimizing dairy for acne.
>Go to a friends wedding, meet one of the best and most impactful friends of my life.
>Start going to gym
>Start going to Dermatologist
>Start seeing results of both, feeling better about myself
>Go outside more, more motivated eat cleaner now and doing that
>Go clothes shopping
>Experiment with my long hair and what I can do with it
>Damn, now I am starting to feel like I'm not ugly and instead kinda attractive
>Go outside, talk to girls and make conversation
>Get a girls number, no answer but hey I did it and I will do it again
That is where I am now, on the horizon
>Going out more
>Getting my license finally, taking myself to gym and running errands myself.
>Looking at schools to go away and make even more of myself, since I can stand on my own two feet mentally finally
Thats the gameplan at least, but I'm trying to convey how small wins motivate you into larger ones. You seem to think like I do so I thought I would try a more personal example to maybe help you visualize it

>You said I am incapable.
different poster, my bad. yes you're always going to carry that shit with you. there's no way around that short of brain damage that affects your memory. cope by lightening the load of what you carry. examine what emotion you're feeling. do this during positive and neutral times too, not just bad. get used to doing it when you don't need to, so that way you're better at it when you do need to. examine the shitty emotions. poke around and see if there are other emotions underneath whatever is the most prominent one. trace each one back to what sparked it. think about how you've chosen to perceive whatever that thing was. yes it was a choice even if it was an auto pilot one you didn't consciously choose. consider it from other perspectives. place value on other aspects of it. what emotion might you be feeling if you had perceived it differently? is that a better emotion? choose to perceive it that way instead then. don't expect immediate results. you might get them but what's more likely is you'll have to repeat this whole song and dance more than once for each 'spark' in order to override the autopilot reaction and reprogram it. it's a pain in the ass but it's absolutely worth doing and you're only incapable if you don't want to.

posts.sub: What are the most effective methods for overcoming porn and masturbation addiction?
posts.com: Title^. What has worked for you anons? Any good sources, books, articles, videos, etc. that helped you or look promising?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
AVRT is the only thing that ever helped me, see https://youtu.be/S53OjsF3z-w. For years I felt totally helpless. I tried nofap and easypeasy but couldnt make it work at all. AVRT however, hits different.

With AVRT you learn that your midbrain has associated your addiction with survival and that it will compel you (your neocortex, your rational thinking self) to use even if it means your own destruction.

Step one in AVRT is to make the "I/IT" distinction. You learn to separate what YOU want from what the primitive (beast) midbrain wants. It will become obvious to you that this is what is really happening in your brain.

Addiction is ambivalence and quitting addiction is putting and end to that ambivalence. Ambivalence means you are of two choices: You really want to keep using porn but at the same time want to quit. You cant reconcile these two extremes and likely do not understand it yet, but its simple. Its I vs IT. The you that matters vs the primitive midbrain beast.

Step two is learning to recognize the addictive voice. Once recognized your thoughts untangle themselves. You decide to stick with your choice instead of what this midbrain compels you to do.

Step three is strengthening your grip over the addictive voice. You mainly do it through the technique of shifting. It means letting the beast out and then reining it in over and over again. You can see it in action in the second part of the video series and its very powerful. It put a tear in my eye because again I realized that for most of my life I have been ruled over by my midbrain.

I cant keep on explaining. Please watch the videos, read the book later. I am very curious what any objection might be to AVRT because from what I can tell its just perfect.

posts.com:
In my case, the books or videos didn't work. What worked out for me was to focus on my behavioral patterns that led to watching porn.
I noticed the most common moment I used to watch porn was when I got home from class/work. I used to get home, take my shoes, get into the bed to relax and eventually I started to search for some porn video. So instead of doing the same, I started to take a shower as soon as I got home, after that I started to cook something and prepare my things for the next day. At some point I started to notice that when I got in bed, I was already too tired to do anything else, so I started to watch less and less porn.
Don't get me wrong, sometimes I still fall for it, especially when I'm free doing nothing, but now I'm not jerking off to porn every single day. Hell, I can even get hard again, and I couldn't do it a year ago.

So my advice is that. Analyze your behavioral patterns, find what are those things that led to you watching porn, and change it. If you notice that you usually watch it at a certain hour, add something else to do at that time of day, like a hobby, working out or anything thab keep your mind busy

It shows you don't understand what addiction is like and have never experienced it. Current research suggests addictions are a mix of compulsion (due to how they change one's brain) and free will (the methods, techniques, and actions that can be taken to help take back control of one's life). The typical conception of libertarian free will is that a person can choose A or not A; with addiction, it's a lot harder for a person to choose not A due to the fundamental changes that take place within their brain.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>27996878
Getting a job with minimal social interaction with the general public would be a good start. Night shift is the easiest way to do this. I only have 3 months of work experience and I'm 25 because I'm in a very similar situation. The only reason I was able to work those 3 months was because it was night shift. I just sent in an application hopefully getting that job back because anxiety got the best of me leading me to quit. I regretted it though because while before I got the job I was also barely able to get out of the house and constantly on edge but after I quit I realized all the progress I made just with the minimal social interactions with co-workers and time at the job was able to keep my mind off my home life all while I was earning my own money. When it comes to your agoraphobia and being on edge, remind yourself that even if you say/do the wrong thing around some stranger first of all they won't think twice about it in the future and you'll almost certainly never see them again anyway. Start off with something you can handle and be responsible with your money so you can get your car fixed. If you're not ready to send out applications quite yet because of the agoraphobia, try setting a chair by your front door and just sit outside for 30 minutes. You can bring your phone or something else to keep you occupied, it's just getting outside that's the important step. Take it from there little by little and go for short 15-30 minute walks, and then see if you're ready to send applications. I've struggled with agoraphobia myself so I'm telling you what I've done. Remember you're not alone either.

There’s no one thing you can do that will make a dramatic difference in your mental state, it’s the accumulation of a bunch of little things.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>27995664
I don't know if it will work with you since everyone's different, but I'll list a few things I do to say functional on the job and in life.
I take notes. I prefer to make them physical, so I have a bunch of post it pads all over my apartment and in my cubical at work. I make it an effort to check the note board every few hours if there is anything new I thought of and need to do.
When a thought comes to me about something I should do, or something to follow up on, I make a note of it ASAP. If you wait, the thought will be gone. Sometimes for hours, sometimes for weeks. Do it as soon as it comes into your mind, and make an active effort to tell yourself "I am going to make a note of that" immediately. For whatever reason it helps me take action then and there. Then put that note onto your primary note board.
When I'm given a big project, or there's something that requires multiple steps in my personal life, I'll make a note of it. Then break it down on the note. Get records, send off the files, receive signatures, collect and organize documents, send to the appropriate individuals, request a follow-up after x time, compile everything, submit complete task to supervisor.
By breaking a big task down visually, on paper, in front of me, it stops me from going down a never ending rabbit hole of panic. It also organizes the process into a list I can simply check off.
Never look beyond the step you're on, on that list. It can overwhelm you. Focus on what needs to be done, force yourself to do it, check off the line item, and keep going with the next step from there. Sometimes I'll take a second sheet of paper and over the other line items so there's only one item to focus on.
I do this for almost everything at this point. Bag lunch for tomorrow, set alarm, sleep, turn off alarm, shower, change, grab bagged lunch, leave for morning commute.
I check them all off on my note board as I go along the routine.
At work I reference my note board first thing.

Dont sign the lease. File a protective order against her. Dont tell her where you are moving. Dont let her in your new apartment.

Tell new apartment that she is a trespasser and not allowed on property. Also show them the OOP. File the OOP about a week before the move so the temporary OOP falls within the move in/out period. If she shows up during that time you can get the cops to take her to jail. The signed order will protect you. Generally you can file those for free at domestic abuse safe places and they will help you file it.

Also take pictures of the apartment now so that if she fucks it up you can blame her.

I’d move out early with a friend while she’s not there. Turn in the key and block all communications along with the above stuff.
